Chapter 7: The Bodhisattva Ground on Subjugation
What is meant by the subjugation of bodhisattvas?
There are six kinds of subjugation:
First, natural subjugation;
Second, subjugation of sentient beings;
Third, subjugation through practice;
Fourth, subjugation through skillful means;
Fifth, subjugation through maturity;
Sixth, subjugation through the seal of maturity.
As for natural subjugation, because one has good seeds, one cultivates wholesome dharmas. Because one cultivates wholesome dharmas, one destroys two kinds of hindrances:
First, the hindrance of afflictions;
Second, the hindrance of wisdom.

Because one cultivates wholesome dharmas, one's body and mind are pure. Because one's body and mind are pure, whether one encounters good friends, buddhas, or bodhisattvas, or does not encounter them, one can destroy the two hindrances of afflictions and wisdom, just as a ripe boil, whether one encounters a doctor or not, can be cured.
It is like a clay vessel, when it is ready for use, it is called mature. Like the mango fruit, when it is ready to be eaten, it is also called mature.
All sentient beings are also like this. When they cultivate the good path and are about to attain anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, this is called mature.
This is called natural discipline.
There are four kinds of disciplined sentient beings:
First, those with the nature of Å›rÄvakas attain the path of Å›rÄvakas;
Second, those with the nature of pratyekabuddhas attain the path of pratyekabuddhas;
Third, those with the nature of buddhas attain the path of buddhas;
Fourth, those with the nature of humans and gods attain the bliss of humans and gods. These are called the four.
This is called disciplined sentient beings.
There are six kinds of disciplined practices:ğŸ”½First, disciplined faculties;
Second, disciplined wholesome roots;
Third, disciplined wisdom;
Fourth, lower discipline;
Fifth, middle discipline;
Sixth, higher discipline.

Those whose faculties are well-tamed, due to the causes and conditions of taming the faculties, attain long life, good appearance, noble lineage, freedom, great strength, subtle and wonderful voice, and the body of a man that is invincible.

Those who fully accomplish this retribution fruit, being able to attain anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, always cultivate ascetic practices for sentient beings, and their minds are never sorrowful, regretful, or resentful, are called those whose faculties are well-tamed.

Those whose wholesome roots are well-tamed, by nature do not delight in creating evil karma, the five hindrances are light, and all evil thoughts gradually weaken, and they enjoy receiving pure and wholesome words, are called those whose wholesome roots are well-tamed.

Those whose wisdom is well-tamed, because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate wisdom, their mental activities are vast and they are well able to uphold and recite the scriptures, understand the meanings of good and evil, contemplate and discern them, and widely explain them to others.
Because of cultivating wisdom, they are able to attain anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
If one can fully subdue the faculties, subdue the roots of goodness, and subdue wisdom, one can purify the obstacle of cognition.

If one fully subdues the faculties, one can purify the obstacle of retribution; if one fully subdues the roots of goodness and wisdom, one can purify the obstacle of cognition and the obstacle of afflictions.
There are two kinds of inferior subduing:
First, because one does not cultivate wholesome dharmas for immeasurable eons;
Second, because one does not delight in seeking the roots of goodness and wisdom, it is called inferior subduing.
Middling subduing means cultivating wholesome dharmas for immeasurable eons, attaining the subduing of the roots of goodness but not wisdom, called middling subduing.
Superior subduing means being fully endowed with the above three things, called superior subduing.
Skillful subduing has twenty-two aspects:
First, the increase of realms;
Second, present causes;
Third, entering the renunciant life;
Fourth, initial arousal [of the mind];
Fifth, not the initial arousal [of the mind];
Sixth, distant purity;
Seventh, being close to purity;
Eighth, adornment;
Ninth, sincerity;
Tenth, giving food;
Eleventh, giving the Dharma;
Twelfth, in order to manifest spiritual powers and generate faith;
Thirteenth, in order to explain the Dharma and generate faith;
Fourteenth, explaining the profound secret treasury and extensively distinguishing the Dharma;
Fifteenth, lower adornment;
Sixteenth, middle adornment;
Seventeenth, upper adornment;
Eighteenth, listening to the Dharma;
Nineteenth, contemplating and cultivating;
Twentieth, embracing;
Twenty-first, reprimanding;
Twenty-second, explaining without being requested and explaining after being requested.
As for the increase of the realm, it is endowed with the seeds of goodness.

Because it is endowed with the seeds of goodness, the roots of goodness in other worlds can further increase. Because one cultivates and accumulates the seeds of the Dharma in the present, the seeds of the Dharma in other worlds can also increase. This is called the increase of the realm.

translated: As for present causes, in the present world, expounding the Dharma without error, listening to the Dharma without error, and correctly upholding it, based on the causes of past lives, enhancing present causes, based on present causes, enhancing future causes, and also enhancing present causes, this is called present causes.

As for entering and leaving the home life, associating with good friends, buddhas, bodhisattvas, giving rise to faith, because of giving rise to faith, abandoning worldly dharmas, receiving and practicing supramundane dharmas.
As for supramundane dharmas, they refer to the bodhisattva precepts.
If one is unable to receive them, a nominally ordained person is not called one who has left the home life, because of severing the dharma of desire one is called one who has left the home life.
One who does not receive such bodhisattva precepts is not called one who has ultimately and permanently severed the dharma of desire.

Severing all craving is called leaving the home life, enjoying ultimate bliss is called leaving the home life, enjoying the easy practice of the path is called leaving the home life, increasing the Buddha Dharma is called leaving the home life, enjoying upholding the precepts is called leaving the home life, this is called entering and leaving the home life.

The initial arousal refers to when one first gives rise to the mind [of enlightenment] and does not delight in saá¹ƒsÄra. Because one does not delight in saá¹ƒsÄra, faith can arise, and one cultivates the path and increases the Buddha's teachings. This is called the initial arousal.

Those who are not initially aroused are those who, after giving rise to the mind [of enlightenment], draw near to the buddhas and the Buddha's disciples, uphold the precepts, recite and copy [sÅ«tras], and widely explain them for others, and so forth, up to increasing the supreme good dharmas. This is called not being initially aroused.

Far purity refers to not upholding the bodhisattva precepts, not being able to recite and copy [sÅ«tras], explain them, or follow the teacher's instructions, being lazy and indolent, and being unable to attain supreme perfect enlightenment for innumerable eons. This is called far purity.

Near purity refers to upholding the precepts, reciting and copying [sÅ«tras], explaining them for others, following the teacher's instructions, diligently cultivating and progressing, and quickly being able to attain supreme perfect enlightenment. This is called near purity.

Adornment means diligently seeking the unsurpassed Buddha Way with utmost sincerity, upholding the bodhisattva precepts for the sake of enlightenment, upholding the bodhisattva precepts out of fear of the king, teachers, elders, and preceptors, and upholding the bodhisattva precepts for the sake of fame. This is called adornment.

Utmost sincerity means being sincere in one's thoughts in the Buddha Dharma, without doubt or resentment, protecting the true Dharma, teaching sentient beings with the bodhisattva canon and bodhisattva precepts, deeply respecting teachers, preceptors, elders, and those with virtue, diligently serving the Three Jewels without rest, and deeply believing that the Three Jewels are eternally abiding and unchanging. This is called utmost sincerity.
Giving food means that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, seeing those who are hungry and destitute, give them food and drink, providing them with all that they need. This is called giving food.

As for giving the Dharma, if a bodhisattva expounds even a single line or verse, or even half a verse, or an entire text or a single canon, extensively for the sake of sentient beings, explaining its meaning, and teaches them to practice good deeds for the sake of enlightenment, this is called giving the Dharma.

As for manifesting spiritual powers to give rise to faith in others, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas manifest great spiritual powers to sentient beings out of compassion, wishing to purify the minds of sentient beings, in order to know that the minds of sentient beings are pure in faith, in order to see that sentient beings are adorned with purity, and in order to cause sentient beings to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment. This is called spiritual powers.

As for expounding the Dharma to give rise to faith in others, a bodhisattva knows that he himself has not yet attained benefit, but in order to benefit others he expounds the Dharma. He also knows that by benefiting others he can eliminate his own faults and thus expounds the Dharma. He also knows that by expounding the Dharma for others he can increase the good deeds he has cultivated. This is called expounding the Dharma.

As for expounding the profound treasury and extensively discriminating the Dharma, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas use skillful means to be able to open and reveal the TathÄgata's profound treasury for sentient beings, in order to enable sentient beings to understand its meaning, and in order to expound the profound meaning for those with wisdom and those who increase their wholesome roots. This is called expounding the profound treasury and extensively discriminating the Dharma.
As for inferior adornment, it refers to being unable to wholeheartedly always practice the unsurpassed holy conduct. This is called inferior adornment.
As for middling adornment, although one wholeheartedly cultivates the holy conduct, one is unable to always practice it. This is called middling adornment.
As for superior adornment, it refers to both being constant and wholeheartedly. This is called superior adornment.

As for listening to the Dharma, when cultivating the unsurpassed Buddha Dharma, one wholeheartedly listens to and collects the twelve divisions of the scriptures, receives and upholds them, writes them out, recites them, and explains them. This is called listening to the Dharma.

Contemplative cultivation means that after listening to the Dharma, the body and mind are tranquil, contemplating the meaning and destroying doubts, cultivating the three perceptions of concentration, wisdom, and equanimity. This is called contemplative cultivation.

Embracing means teaching the Dharma for others with an unattached mind, accepting disciples and instructing them well, providing them with robes, alms bowl, and medicine when sick, knowing when afflictions arise and teaching the Dharma according to the illness. This is called embracing.

Reproaching means if one knows and sees the afflictions that arise, one should reproach the body and mind. One who gives rise to afflictions cannot benefit oneself or others. One should see light offenses as medium and medium offenses as heavy. Just as a person with a disturbed mind falls into a pit, after falling one should not fall again. If afflictions arise, one should subdue them.
If one sees disciples giving rise to slight afflictions, one should reproach them. One should not accept their prostrations, offerings, or even toothpicks and water for washing.
If they commit grave offenses, one should perform the karman of expulsion.
If one reproaches, it is for one's own benefit and the benefit of others. This is called reproach.

As for not waiting to be asked to speak, it is for one's own benefit to uphold, recite, and explain the profound meaning, to destroy the afflictions that arise in sentient beings, and to increase the good dharmas that sentient beings practice, and thus to speak the Dharma.
As one upholds oneself, one speaks as one upholds, and abides by the Dharma.
Why is this?
If a bodhisattva does not abide by the Dharma, sentient beings will look down on him and say:
You yourself are unable to abide by the Dharma, so how can you teach others?
You should now receive the Dharma from others, so how can you turn around and speak the Dharma for others?
This is called not waiting to be asked to speak.

As for waiting to be asked to speak, it is like upholding the precepts, diligently cultivating and progressing, being replete with good roots, delighting in dwelling in solitude, always being respected by all, and people believing and accepting what one expounds, knowing the meaning and the words, and being able to skillfully speak the Dharma.

In order to tame sentient beings without inherent nature, they speak of the bliss of humans and gods, causing them to attain nonretrogression. For those with inherent nature, they speak to cause them to attain taming and the growth of wholesome dharmas. This is called 'taming through maturity.'

Chapter 8: Bodhi, Part of the Bodhisattva Ground What is called bodhi?
Bodhi refers to two kinds of liberation and two kinds of wisdom.
The two kinds of liberation are: first, liberation from the afflictive hindrances;
second, liberation from the cognitive hindrances.
The two kinds of wisdom are: first, the ability to destroy the afflictive hindrances;
second, the ability to destroy the cognitive hindrances.
Moreover, unsurpassed bodhi refers to pure wisdom, unobstructed wisdom, omniscience, the severing of all habitual tendencies, and the elimination of all indeterminate ignorance.
Pure wisdom refers to the severing of all habitual tendencies, the knowledge of all realms, all dharmas, all practices, all worlds, all times, and all antidotes.
There are two kinds of realms:
first, the world;
second, the realm of sentient beings.
Dharmas are also of two kinds:
first, conditioned;
second, unconditioned.
Practices are also of two kinds:
First, destroying the afflictive hindrances;
Second, destroying the hindrances to wisdom.
There are two kinds of worldly people:
First, the wise;
Second, the foolish.
There are three kinds of time:
Past, present, and future.
There are three kinds of antidotes:
The contemplation of impurity, the contemplation of kindness, and the contemplation of the twelve links of dependent origination.
This is called pure wisdom.

Unimpeded wisdom means not relying on adornments or contemplation to enter concentration, but being able to penetrate all realms, all dharmas, all practices, all worlds, all times, and all antidotes. This is called unimpeded wisdom.
Furthermore, there is unimpeded wisdom, namely the one hundred and forty unshared dharmas.
The TathÄgata's unobstructed samÄdhi, knowledge of aspirations, and four unimpeded knowledges are called unimpeded wisdom, which is called bodhi.
What are the one hundred and forty unshared dharmas?

Namely, the thirty-two marks, the eighty minor marks, the four pure practices, the ten powers, the four fearlessnesses, the three foundations of mindfulness, the three non-protections, great compassion, non-forgetfulness, severing all habits, and the unsurpassed knowledge of all practices. These are called the one hundred and forty uncommon dharmas, which will be extensively explained later in the chapter on abodes.
What is called unsurpassed enlightenment?
Because it is endowed with seven kinds of unsurpassedness, it is called unsurpassed enlightenment.
First, the unsurpassed body;
second, the unsurpassed upholding;
third, the unsurpassed fulfillment;
fourth, the unsurpassed wisdom;
fifth, the unsurpassed inconceivability;
sixth, the unsurpassed liberation;
seventh, the unsurpassed practice.
As for the unsurpassed body, it is because the body is adorned with the thirty-two marks.
As for the unsurpassed upholding, it is because the buddhas and bodhisattvas benefit themselves and others and are able to bestow upon sentient beings the happiness of humans and gods.
As for being endowed with the unsurpassed, buddhas and bodhisattvas have four endowments, namely: endowment with lifespan, endowment with vision, endowment with precepts, and endowment with practice.
As for the unsurpassed wisdom, it refers to the four unobstructed [abilities].
As for the unsurpassed inconceivability, it refers to being endowed with the six perfections.
As for the unsurpassed liberation, it is because the TathÄgata is able to destroy the two kinds of hindrances.
As for the unsurpassed practice, it refers to the holy practices, heavenly practices, and brahma practices.
The holy practices refer to the three samÄdhis of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, and the concentration of cessation.
The heavenly practices refer to the four dhyÄnas and the four formless concentrations.
The brahma practices refer to the four immeasurable [minds].
These three kinds of practices surpass the Buddha's four practices, which he always delights in cultivating.
What are the four holy practices?
There are two:
First, the samÄdhi of emptiness;
Second, the concentration of cessation.
The heavenly practice has one, namely the fourth dhyÄna.
The practice of austerity is also one, namely great compassion.

The TathÄgata, for the sake of great compassion, always observes sentient beings six times a day and night, thinking: Who lacks good roots? I shall bestow seeds upon them. Who has planted good roots? I shall cause them to grow. Moreover, who has not yet given rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment? I shall cause them to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

Because the TathÄgata has this unsurpassed body, he is called a great man. Because he upholds the unsurpassed, he is called great compassion. Because he is fully endowed with the unsurpassed, he is called one who has reached the other shore. Because his wisdom is unsurpassed, he is called omniscient. Because he is inconceivable and unsurpassed, he is called an Arhat. Because his liberation is unsurpassed, he is called great nirvÄá¹‡a. For this reason, the TathÄgata is fully endowed with ten kinds of names and epithets, namely TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, Endowed with Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the World, Unsurpassed One, Tamer of Men, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One.
Because there is no falsehood, he is called the TathÄgata.
Because he is a good field of blessings, he is called the Arhat.
Because he knows the Dharma realm, he is called the Perfectly Enlightened One.
Because he is endowed with the three kinds of clear knowledge, he is called the One Endowed with Knowledge and Conduct.
Because he does not come back, he is called the Well-Gone.
Because he knows the two kinds of worlds, he is called the Knower of the World:
First, the world of lands;
Second, the world of sentient beings.
Because he is able to subdue the physical and mental evils of sentient beings, he is called the Unsurpassed One, the Tamer of Men, and because he is able to be the eyes for sentient beings.

Able to cause sentient beings to correctly understand the true Dharma and true meaning, because he extensively explains the meaning for sentient beings, is able to destroy all afflictions and suffering, is able to break through the web of doubt in the minds of sentient beings, reveals the profound meaning of all dharmas, and is the root of all good dharmas, therefore he is called the teacher of gods and humans.

For countless eons, not a single Buddha appears in the world, therefore it is difficult to attain.

Innumerable worlds have innumerable Buddhas, and the worlds of the ten directions have innumerable Bodhisattvas, who simultaneously and with the same vows cultivate and adorn [the path to Buddhahood], simultaneously and at the same time giving rise to the mind of enlightenment, at the same time, on the same day, in the same month, and in the same year, equally practicing giving, morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom. For this reason, there should be innumerable and boundless Buddha lands in the worlds of the ten directions.

In one land, two Buddhas never appear in the world at the same time. If there are no innumerable and boundless worlds in the ten directions, would the innumerable and boundless Bodhisattvas who cultivate good practices have no fruits [of their practice]?
For this reason, we know that there are innumerable and boundless Buddha worlds in the ten directions.
Why is it so?
Because there are no two Buddhas in one land.

If there were the appearance of two Buddhas in one land, sentient beings would not enjoy cultivating wholesome dharmas, and would not give rise to the thought of respect for the difficulty of encountering [a Buddha].

The Buddhas of the ten directions, except for four matters, are all equal and non-dual in everything else:

Chapter 9: The Nature of the Power of Bodhi Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who wish to study the bodhisattva precepts should cultivate faith and understanding, always delight in seeking the Dharma and always delight in expounding the Dharma, deeply give rise to offerings upon seeing those who uphold the Dharma, abide in accordance with the Dharma, teach and admonish disciples to abide in the true Dharma, and skillfully understand the skillful means of the actions of body, speech, and mind.
How do bodhisattvas cultivate faith and understanding?

Clearly believing in the Three Jewels and their merits, believing in the inconceivable nature of the Buddha and bodhisattvas, believing in the true meaning, believing in cause and effect, believing that all sentient beings have various kinds of karma and various kinds of karmic fruits, understanding skillful means and what is not skillful means, and believing that one will certainly attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
One should know that one has attained the meaning, which refers to supreme enlightenment, the enlightenment of wisdom, and the enlightenment of skillful means.
Skillful means refers to the bodhisattva precepts up to the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
The bodhisattva precepts are to patiently believe and accept the teachings when hearing the Dharma.
The twelve divisions of the canon are called the bodhisattva precepts.
Those who study the bodhisattva precepts should cultivate two things:
First, a compassionate mind;
Second, a faithful mind. The bodhisattva cultivates these two dharmas and attains a mind of faith and understanding.
What does one seek when seeking the Dharma?

Why does one seek?

There are five kinds of techniques:
First, internal techniques;
Second, causal techniques;
Third, linguistic techniques;
Fourth, knowing the causes of illness and the methods of curing illness;

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always seek these five kinds of methods.
The inner method refers to the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas seek the twelve divisions of the scriptures for two reasons:

Second, to know that one's actions are not lost, and that one does not experience what one has not done.
Seeking cause-based treatises is for two reasons: First, to understand the faults of non-Buddhist teachings;
Second, to refute the various treatises of non-Buddhist teachers.
Seeking treatises on sound is also for two reasons: First, to understand the meanings of all phenomena;
Second, to rectify all spoken sounds.
Seeking medical techniques is for four reasons: First, to understand the symptoms of illness;
Second, to understand the causes of illness;
Third, to understand the cure for illness;
Fourth, to understand how to prevent illness from recurring after it has been cured.

Seeking the twelve divisions of the scriptures for those who know cause and effect, all dharmas have ten kinds of causes. The characteristics of true causes encompass all causes, whether of birth and death, liberation, good, evil, internal, external, sentient beings, or non-sentient beings.
What are the ten?
First, the cause of dissemination;
Second, the cause of origination;
Third, the cause of creation;
Fourth, the cause of inclusion;
Fifth, the cause of growth;
Sixth, the cause of transformation;
Seventh, the cause of non-commonality;
Eighth, the cause of commonality;
Ninth, the cause of harm;
Tenth, the cause of non-harm.

The cause of dissemination refers to the cause of dharmas by which one obtains their essence and characteristics through names. Because one obtains their essence and characteristics, they can be proclaimed. This is called the cause of dissemination.
For example, taking with the hands, traveling with the feet, and coming and going, sitting and lying down with the body, these are called the cause of origination.
For example, obtaining fruits from seeds, this is called the cause of creation.
The cause of obtaining fruits from other than the seed is called the inclusive cause.
The sprout arises from the seed's cessation, and the fruit is obtained from the sprout, which is called the cause of growth.
Like the grain arising from the seed, and the seed arising from the grain, this is called the transforming cause.
Obtaining the fruit according to the seed is called the exclusive cause.
Earth, water, fire, and wind are called the common causes.
Violating the four grave prohibitions and harming good dharmas is called the harmful cause.
If one does not violate them, it is called the non-harming cause.
There are five harmful causes:
First, the harm of sound;
Second, the harm of birth;
Third, the harm of not living together;
Fourth, the harm of enmity;
Fifth, the harm of concentration.
The harm of sound is like worldly discussions, first speaking well and later speaking unwholesomely.
Moreover, harm is like saying that all dharmas are impermanent like empty space, and saying that everything is permanent referring to birth, aging, and death. This is called the harm of sound.
The harm of arising means, for example, saying that without a cause one can produce a result, or that there is a cause but no result.
The harm of not coexisting means, for example, like light and darkness, greed and anger, suffering and joy.
The harm of enmity means, for example, like a snake and a rat, a wolf and a horse, a water buffalo and a cat, or a cat and a rat.

The harm of concentration means, for example, like the contemplation of impurity eliminating greed, loving-kindness eliminating anger, compassion eliminating the mind of harm, and the eightfold noble path eliminating all bonds.
There are two more causes:
The first is the true cause;
The second is the expedient cause.
The true cause refers to the seeds.
The expedient cause is like the other external conditions.
The expedient cause has four kinds of conditions:
The first is the causal condition;
The second is the sequential condition;
The third is the object condition;
The fourth is the dominant condition.
The causal condition is the cause for the arising of all dharmas.
The dominant condition refers to the expedient cause.
The sequential condition and the object condition refer to the mind and mental factors.
These are called the four conditions.
How do these ten causes give rise to all worldly and supramundane dharmas?
How does one cut off birth and death?
How does one not cut off birth and death?

In the world, there are various grains with various names for the sake of nourishing life, such as barley, wheat, soybeans, mung beans, rice, sesame, and so forth. This is called the cause of distribution.
Because of hunger and thirst, one lacks strength. In order to eliminate this affliction and obtain physical strength, one seeks barley, wheat, and even sesame.
Because of craving for delicious food, one gives rise to a greedy mind. Because of the greedy mind, one seeks them by skillful means. This is called the cause of origination.
Like those seeds giving rise to similar fruits, this is called the cause of production.
Like those earth, water, fire, wind, manure, labor, and so forth, this is called the cause of inclusion.
From the growth of the seeds up to the fruit, this is called the cause of increase.
It is like a seed producing a fruit, and from the fruit producing the cause again. This is called the transforming cause.
It is like wheat producing wheat, and beans producing beans themselves. This is called the exclusive cause.
It is like producing a fruit from something other than a seed. This is called the common cause.
It is like a seed encountering hail, being burned by fire, or being eaten by birds. This is called the harmful cause.
Apart from hail, fire, and birds, it is called the harmless cause.
For this reason, these ten causes give rise to worldly dharmas and supramundane dharmas.

What is called a result?
There are five kinds of results:
First, the result of retribution;
Second, the remaining result;
Third, the result of liberation;
Fourth, the result of present action;
Fifth, the dominant result.
Unwholesome dharmas receive the three evil retributions. Wholesome dharmas with outflows receive the fruits of humans and gods. This is called the result of retribution.
Because of creating evil, one delights in evil karma. Because of cultivating goodness, one delights in cultivating wholesome karma. This is called the remaining result.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, by understanding cause and effect, increase their power of action and cultivate the path, knowing that if one does not act, one does not receive, and that the fruit of action is not lost.

Bodhisattvas single-mindedly think of the bodhisattva precepts and diligently seek the Buddha's teachings, even a single sentence, verse, or meaning.

If one sees the expounder, one should give rise to respect, joy, and delight in listening, not belittling the Dharma expounder, not seeking faults in the Dharma expounder, and respectfully receiving it as if hearing it from the Buddha himself.

Listening to the Dharma with utmost sincerity, one respects the expounder and values the Dharma. This is called a bodhisattva who is fully endowed with the bodhisattva precepts.

There are four ways of listening to the Dharma:
First, with utmost sincerity;
Second, with a one-pointed mind;
Third, with the whole mind;
Fourth, with a wholesome mind.
This is called a bodhisattva diligently seeking the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
Why do bodhisattvas seek the twelve divisions of the scriptures?

In order to spread the true Dharma of the buddhas, in order to increase the buddhadharmas, in order to cause the world to have faith in the Buddha's teachings, and in order to cause all immeasurable sentient beings to attain supreme perfect enlightenment, bodhisattvas seek the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
Why do bodhisattvas seek the treatises on causes?

In order to know the faults of treatises on causes, in order to refute the evil and deviant treatises of non-Buddhists, in order to know the skillful means of taming sentient beings, and in order to distinguish the meaning of the TathÄgata's words and the meaning of worldly words, bodhisattvas seek the treatises on causes.
Why do bodhisattvas seek the treatises on sound?

In order to purify one's speech and adorn it, because impure words cannot clearly proclaim the definitive meaning, in order to understand all meanings, to destroy incorrect speech and the arrogant mind, to destroy wrong views, and to know the skillful means to tame sentient beings, therefore the Bodhisattva seeks out the science of language.
Why does the Bodhisattva seek out medical prescriptions?

In order to free sentient beings from the four hundred and four diseases, out of compassion, in order to tame sentient beings, in order to give rise to the mind of faith, in order to give rise to the mind of joy, therefore the Bodhisattva seeks out medical prescriptions.
Why does the Bodhisattva seek out worldly techniques?

In order to easily obtain wealth and benefits for sentient beings, in order to give rise to the mind of faith in sentient beings, in order to know worldly affairs and destroy arrogance, in order to tame sentient beings, in order to destroy all the darkness and hindrances to the Dharma.

If a bodhisattva cannot seek these five things in this way, he will never be able to attain supreme perfect enlightenment and accomplish omniscience. It is for the sake of attaining supreme perfect enlightenment that he seeks these five things.
